"Netorare basically means having a loved one stolen from someone [...]" if we are going by this definition, then, what sort of evidence pertaining to how the author shows Sakie and Tetsuo's relationship supports the argument for adding the tag? It can be said that Tetsuo in this doujin is just being the "nice co-worker" type person who does not have any romantic feelings at all whereas Sakie (the person whose perspective is more strongly shown) could be mistaking Tetsuo's actions and misinterpreting them as romantic gestures. Furthermore, the trope of "love interest visits main character's house" is not entirely a foreign concept to the anime industry, thus the netorare tag being added could possibly be a mistake caused by misinterpretation of the character's relationship (calling Sakie the "loved one" of Tetsuo is also a stretch, as there isn't ant significant indication of her holding such a status in the canon and in this doujin).

This assertion is further supported by the fact of which there is no solid indication that Tetsuo (the male character Sakie Satou is in love with) necessarily has (concrete) romantic feelings towards her to begin with (in the canon) and includes his surprise at how she presents herself towards him by the end of the doujin (which can be more attributed to actual surprise in consideration of Sakie's sudden character/personality change plus getting a strong hit of the Succubi's aphrodisiac pheromones). Also, the author keeps the Tetsuo and Sakie's relationship in the doujin (as it may stray from the canon), thus further complicating the tag.

And even by using the link you provide, which upon going deeper by a simply clicking the text "Netorare" then redirects the user to "Infidelity", which "is a violation of a couple's assumed or stated contract regarding emotional and/or sexual exclusivity. Other scholars define infidelity as a violation according to the subjective feeling that one's partner has violated a set of rules or relationship norms; this violation results in feelings of sexual jealousy and rivalry." As such, your argument can be moreso based upon subjectivity in regards to netorare rather than objectivity. From this perspective, I can see how such a thought process is indeed possible to concieve, but in terms of objectiveness, it fails to properly categorize the tag as a whole.

Then perhaps you are also arguing that wikipedia is also just as valid for your argument? Absurd. In consideration of your ad hominem (which is a logical fallacy, thus reducing the effectiveness of your argument), I find your verbose and quite rude language rather uncalled for.

Ntr is not the same thing as cuckolding you retarded piece of shit and it doesnt literally means cuckold read and learn from an actual source instead of the tvtropes bullshit which could be edited by others  you retarded cocksucker faggot who uses shitbag instead of brain  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NTR Let me copy paste it for you retarded bitch " a Japanese slang term (寝取られ, litetarally "taken away by sleeping with") often abbreviated NTR" Cuckold implies that there is a relationship between partners whereas netoarer could also be between a mother and a son even though they dont  have any sexual relationship  or a sister and brother without sexual relationship so cuckolding is not the literal translation of ntr. Netorare basically means having a loved one stolen from someone and that is totally possible without cheating unlike  cuckolding.
Lastly, why the fuck are we even having this conversation to begin with? You can BLACKLIST SPECIFIC TAGS. It's a bloody feature. Check on the info page to figure out how to use it.

Furthermore, the "cuckold" tag is noticeably missing from the full list, which lends more support. This is primarily due to the fact that "cuckold" is best defined as "A "cuckold" is a man whose Love Interest has sex with someone else, either to his dismay or without his knowledge." To this end, it is reasonable to have this definition be attached to the "netorare" tag, as this fits within the premises of the doujin's content (Sakie has sex with someone else without her love interest's knowledge).

"Dont know what ntr really means"

Another way to look at is the Japanese equivalent of cuckolding (which can cause a problem as whoever is doing the tagging is failing to do their job). The literal translation from the Japanese word "寝取られ" into English is, in fact, "cuckold". In fact, TVTropes makes a wonderful analysis on the genre and how the more correct usage would be "cuckold" instead of whatever emotion-induced definition you seem to have. This is the link: https://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Analysis/Netorare
Lucifer-san You are retarded and obviously  dont know what ntr really means. If ntr was same as cheating there wouldnt be separate tags for two of them you moron.

NTR is defined in a similar way as cheating, infidelity, or adultery.
